comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: The musical 'Madame Pompadour' had a couple of runs in Australia in the 1920s and 1930s. The 1920s version featured the Dutch star Beppie de Vries in the title role...the 1930s version featured the English star Sylvia Welling...of the two, Beppie de Vries is perhaps the closest match to the woman we see here...but just going on this SLNSW pic, I'm pretty sure it's not her acms.sl.nsw.gov.au//item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=442750 . Of all the many possibilities...one is that the woman we see here is in fancy dress costume (!), and that her choice of attire was inspired by 'Madame Pompadour'...though the costume really looks a cut above the average fancy dress outfit...so if my 'Madame Pompadour' guess is a dud...I'd still tend to think that there might be a professional stage connection here... Similar backdrop to www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/8532158815/in/photo... and www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/8433103969/in/photo...

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Thanks for the links - these portraits are tantalising. I agree with you that the quality of the costumes indicates these are professional performers. Perhaps there was a theatre company in town as Hall has quite a number of studio portraits of people wearing elaborate costumes... I have a feeling we'll get to the bottom of this one eventually!
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment._content: news.google.com/newspapers?id=wlwRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LpYDA... ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article84900409 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article37668168 some of these 1920s J.C. Williamson Gilbert & Sullivan costumes look vaguely similar...links parked here for possible future reference...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article128525631 per this Sunday Times item, a Madame Pompadour night was held at the Wentworth Hotel in August 1927...Wentworth manager Hannah Maclurkin put up a prize of ten pounds for the best costume...Beppie de Vries (star of the stage production) was evidently appointed judge. I wonder whether this women might have been a contestant... [a bit later] However, on checking a few more digitised newspapers, I now realise that 'Madame Pompadour' was a popular fancy dress character in Sydney in the 1927-1928 period and beyond...over at SLNSW there's a couple of Sam Hood pics which show a number of lesser examples acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=9896 ; acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=9879 ; even the ankle biters were in on the act acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=42955 ...so I'm kind of back to where I was 7 months ago on this one...maybe just a tad more convinced there is a 'Madame Pompadour' connection...but beyond this still clueless.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] I've had a look at the strips that go along the top of these Hall portraits (old tape - you can see them in some of these digital files) and the writing on this neg is confusing. It has what appears to be '4 sepia panels' and another panel that looks like 'Mrs Bouche' or perhaps 'Bourke'. we do have a Miss Bouche but she looks decidedly different! The 1927 Wentworth Hotel connection is interesting, particularly as we now know the portraits of Peggy Petite were taken at this time when she was performing at the Wentworth.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
